comments.commentBody: Rest in Peace Mr. Gandolfini.
it was GET  Shorty, but glad you got it, especially since Itzkoff finished with the question about Gandolfini not doing more comedies. He played Bear, and a big ol' good-natured teddy he was

Not many celebrity deaths shock me, but this one does. Or maybe it's just the sadness of it. He was the consummate actor and his Tony Soprano a defining role for him and a grand experience for all of us who watched him so perfectly portray the complicated Tony. James Gandolfini, you will be missed. RIP.

I just watched an episode of the Sopranos this week on HBO.  It was the one where Tony & Carmella were separated and the Black Bear comes into their yard.  God I just can't believe this.  James Gandolfini was so great in that role!

He lived life to the fullest...followed his muse once he found it in acting class...and left so many of us saying, "Wow." The personality, the command of the screen, the immensity of the TS persona...all bigger than life and all will be missed and never matched in future hoodlums. Gotta go get the complete set now....and watch "Killing Them Softly..." when I get a chance to see him in a different light. Thanks, James G!
What a loss to his family...and his fans!!  A great actor and wonderful human being by all accounts.

Entire movie is priceless.  Entire cast is priceless.  His role in this ensemble merely added to his incredibly-great comic talent, much of which was overlooked during the run of  "The Sopranos."  So bloody talented, such a soulful face - even on-stage, he had the capacity to say or do very little and convey all those emotions one usually only see up-close on screen.  A true original, he will be missed by many.

I will forever love his role as a general in the film “In the Loop.” The scene in which this big bear of a man escapes a party and repairs to a child’s bedroom, tallying the Iraq war on a tiny talking calculator that makes cartoon noises, is priceless.

So sorry to hear this news.  Though living now in SF, i was born and raised in New Jersey.  James was yet another reason to be proud of my roots.  He expressed a Jersey sensibility and aura that made (makes) me proud.  A true talent.  Sincere condolences to his family and friends.
Your talent, humanity, and art will be sorely missed.  God Speed Mr. Gandolfini!
Character is measured by what you do when nobody is watching.
I don't know what it is but the death of some people hit you like a Mack truck and it's only then that you realize how much their work deeply affected you without your consciously knowing it,

Sad beyond words...I've been watching The Sopranos in reruns even though I saw the original series as well as an earlier set of via Netflix, I think. His character was a wonderful study of the complex human being, and his cohorts were fabulous as they worked off his character.

It would have been wonderful to see how he used is gifts as he aged but we have been denied that opportunity. RIP Tony, errr, James and thank you for what you gave of yourself.
This is a terrible loss.
How sad. RIP James!

That's the lesson.

RIP James Gandolfini.

Life is short. Make the most of every moment.
so sad- so much more to give...

IMHO, this is a prevalent attitude about rules and laws amongst us baby boomers. The Not-in-my-back-yard (NIMBY) syndrome is a subset of this meme. Hey, I'm not perfect, but the hypocrisy is breathtaking.
This newly crafted rule: I love and accept my immediate family and am utterly indifferent to the rest of humanity — this signals the end of civic sanity.

It's interesting that you mention the lack of sidewalks in some  neighborhoods. It's very telling.  It certainly shows that a community doesn't give any value at all to the lives of people who  don't  own a car and must walk.

The loss of a mutually held feeling of fairness is a fundamental threat to democracy-unfairness is not having a living wage or a good community.

A practical example is the big city where I live--there are many areas where poorer and working class people live where there are no sidewalks along 4 lane roads. The cars zoom by, while people are walking to get groceries and darting across where there are no traffic lights. It is not unusual to hear about people being struck and killed...yet this city can finance new stadiums . That is the erosion of fairness.

Charles Murray and David Brooks explaining all the ills in the United States as stemming from hippie culture in the 1960's is just a gigantic distortion. American life was pretty good for white America in the 60's. Violence came from fighting against racism and from fighting against an illegal war when American Institutions were not responsive enough and were complicit in the prolongation of war + poverty.
But there was so much good in the 1960's too. Young people decided that racism and sexism was just not going to be tolerated anymore. The Democratic party looked more and more like America with the inspirations of Barbara Jordan, Bobby Kennedy and Frank Church. We were proud of the Peace Corps and Earth Day.

In the 1970's when companies started to close their factories in the little and big towns across America is when the erosion of American culture began. That had nothing to do with hippies nor narcissism.

This is a great topic to come up with approaching the 150th anniversary of the Battle of Gettysburg.  It was the national disgrace and injustice of slavery that led to that massive conflagration, but although that particular injustice would be extinct as a legal institution within two and a half years, many other injustices remained, including the unjust treatment of women.  Too many people focus too much on the fighting itself and forget what the fighting was really all about.  Not states' rights but individual rights -- the ongoing struggle to recognize and enforce by law the equal rights of all humans, regardless of skin tone, ethnicity, gender, etc.  The Confederacy was struggling for the "right" of some people to trample on the rights of others, to expand injustice.  The Union may not have been explicitly struggling to undo all the wrongs brought about by slavery, nevertheless its triumph over the Confederacy helped extinguish that blight and ensured that the nation would continue, however slowly and awkwardly, on the path of expanding the rights of all people within the soon to be reunited nation.
Boyd.

The horrendous differences between the salaries of workers and CEOs, the pervasive corruption among politicians and business operatives, the absence of Ethics, in one word, are World Wide phenomena. These problems are not unique to the US. Just read the news from Europe, Brazil, China  . . . Structurally, in the US we have a service sector, the Financial sector, that has supplanted the productive sector, and the financial crisis has not altered much that relation. As a result of this and other reasons, we are failing to compete in the global economy, while other countries have been doing very well, e.g., Germany. I heard one of our Union leaders asking in a TV program why is that Germany can pay those salaries and benefits without outsourcing its production, and we have too.  Why? The ethical problems do not lie in the middle class, or working class but in the upper-class. If the prospects for a just distribution of resources look bad with Obama, do you imagine how those prospects will be with Mitt Romney and Co.  I wonder if David Brooks will consider Mitt Romney and Co examples of narcissism.

Mark,

I thought you had started to read "Reinventing Fire." Cost curves for transportation are pretty stunning.

Complaining about the cost of storage seems rather silly. Were New York to embark on this project, they'd be the first adopter market for the used batteries from the Leaf and Volt on an alpha test basis so the storage would likely be a freebee. And, as pointed out by Lovins in the book "Reinventing Fire" fuel cell vehicles lag electric vehicles by only a few years in becoming cheaper than internal combustion vehicles. And that happens well before 2030. So the Jacobson et al. transportation conversion certainly saves money rather than costing extra. It seems at though the Carnegie group has made the common error of not comparing the alternative cost. Oil at $200/barrel in say 2023 makes transportation conversion cheap even at a cash-for-clunkers-type pace which retires the gasoline based fleet faster than it wears out.

I suspect that there is a fundamental lack of understanding concerning how distributed generation affects reliability. Lovins' "Transform" scenario is considered the most reliable with intrinsic robustness against extreme weather and large solar flare events.

Perhaps "reality check" is not the correct description for the Carnegie endeavor.
It isn't a social movement.
